name: Chamomile (Matricaria recutita, Chamaemelum nobile)
summary: A traditional herbal remedy widely used for anxiety, insomnia, and digestive discomfort, supported by some clinical evidence for mild-to-moderate anxiety and sleep improvement.
description: Chamomile is one of the most commonly used medicinal herbs worldwide, prepared as teas, extracts, or essential oils. It contains bioactive compounds such as apigenin, luteolin, and bisabolol, which contribute to its anxiolytic, sedative, anti-inflammatory, and gastrointestinal-calming properties. Clinical studies suggest benefits in mild-to-moderate generalized anxiety disorder, sleep quality, and gastrointestinal health. Chamomile is generally well tolerated but may cause allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to plants in the Asteraceae family. It can also interact with anticoagulants and sedatives.

metadata.natural_source: Flower heads of Matricaria recutita (German chamomile) or Chamaemelum nobile (Roman chamomile)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

contraindications: Allergy to ragweed, daisies, chrysanthemums (Asteraceae family)
Pregnancy (safety not fully established at high doses)
monitoring_required: Bleeding risk in patients on anticoagulants

sections.text: Chamomile flavonoids such as apigenin bind to benzodiazepine receptors in the brain, enhancing GABAergic neurotransmission and producing anxiolytic and sedative effects. Anti-inflammatory compounds such as bisabolol and chamazulene reduce cytokine activity, supporting gastrointestinal and skin healing.

adult.typical: 220–1100 mg/day of standardized extract; or 1–3 cups of chamomile tea brewed from 2–3 g dried flowers
adult.note: Higher doses may cause sedation; extracts standardized to apigenin are preferred in studies.

sections.pediatric: 1–2 cups of weak tea for children >5 years old; not recommended in infants due to risk of contamination and allergies

sections.text: Onset: Within 30–60 minutes (tea or extract). Duration: Effects last 4–6 hours.

other: Avoid in individuals with ragweed or related allergies.
Caution with concurrent sedatives or anticoagulants.
Not recommended in pregnancy in medicinal doses.

items: Sedation level if combined with CNS depressants

sections.pregnancy: Avoid high doses; mild tea may be safe
sections.lactation: Likely safe in moderate amounts (tea); avoid concentrated extracts
sections.pediatrics: Mild tea may be safe for older children; avoid in infants
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for excess sedation

sections.text: Not required; no withdrawal symptoms expected.

items: One of the best-studied herbal teas for anxiety and sleep.
Clinical trial evidence supports efficacy for generalized anxiety disorder.
Chamomile is often used in integrative care for sleep hygiene and stress management.

items.label: Amsterdam JD et al. Chamomile for Generalized Anxiety Disorder. J Clin Psychopharmacol. 2009
